Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2008 10:27AM Rebecca wrote: Hello Emma, and a warm welcome to you.  This is indeed a wonderful place to go to find information and support.  This is a very scary time for you...there is nothing more frightening than the unknown.  You are moving in the correct direction...that you are already scheduled for your diagnostic procedures means that you are already doing everything that you could possibly do.  I understand you fear based on your family history, and I can assure you that great strides have been made in the diagnosis and treatment of BC.  The treatments today are not like what you probably remember....they are not fun, but it is something that you can live through, and then go on to  live many years AFTER.  I am hoping for benign results for you...do check back and let us know how you are doing.
Posts.Title: fear of possible bc diagnosis Emma56 Emma56

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2008 11:35AM Rebecca wrote: LuAnn that is exactly what I was thinking...if they put you on Zoladex to shut down ovaries, you should then be able to take the AI.  Maybe you need to be on the Zoladex for a while before they can start giving it. I think that there are other options before putting you on chemo again.  Hang in there!  HUGS!
Posts.Title: Not Menopausal - No Arimidex jonimb Maya1

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2008 07:28AM Rebecca wrote: Well from what you described I would definately vote for a case of shingles. It sounds to me like your lump is very likely an infected or inflamed lymph node. That said, I am NOT a medical doctor, and it is difficult if not impossible to diagnose anything over the internet.  The only way to know for sure is to see your Dr...the sooner the better. I hear your concerns regarding the medical community, and in particular the insurance companies, but you must remember that your health is more important than anything else.  Do not let yourself be paralyzed by fear....there are systems in place that can offer help to indivuals such as yourself.  See your Dr and then check back and let us know how you did. Feel better, and good luck!

Please hang in there...huge hugs to you!

Be strong, keep your head high and smile.  Be well, and stay in touch...the women here are wonderful, supportive and a bottomless well of information.

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2007 03:45AM Rebecca wrote: I had my first chemo session on Jan 18, and I am almost all the way through the first cycle now. It was not as dreadful as I had imagined, but it was no walk in the park either. Thank goodness for modern medicine, I did not throw up even once. My hair started to fall out on Day 15, and I think I took it pretty well, all things considered. When it started to fall, I took a buzzer to it. It made a dreadful mess, but I felt so much better when it was over. I think the scariest thing is doing this alone....I am glad I do not have to. Keep the faith ladies...together we can do anything
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in JAN 2007 Robbin65 Robbin65

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2007 04:38AM Rebecca wrote: I know it is hard...and I think the most important thing is to do what is best for you! I did my hair in stages too. I had very long hair before my diagnosis, and two days after my surgery I got a very short haircut. (I saved my hair, and plan to donate it to Locks of Love at then end). I left it that way as it started to thin, but when it really started to fall I found it so upsetting that I just buzzed it off. I still have hair, but it is more stubble than anything right now...and I have big bald spots now. I did not think I would be able to look at myself with no (or shaved) hair, but I found it was not as bad as I anticipated. Stay strong....I think that it is a true act of bravery to cut off you hair, regardless of whether you look. Always remember that you are beautiful, particularly to those who love you.

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2007 05:32AM Rebecca wrote: Well Amera I think that is a good question. The way that personally have been viewing it is that in the process of getting rid of the cancer (surgery, chemo etc) is also the process of "dying" as a cancer patient, and being reborn as a survivor at the end. After all, when it is done, many of us will be re-entering mainstream life much as we entered it the first time...bald and weak. I am not sure at which point I will view my rebirth as complete, but I imagine that it will be the first day after treatment is completed that I feel "normal" again. I plan to celebrate when it happens.

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2007 10:50AM Rebecca wrote: oh..and Jan, as far as the expander process goes...I had the expander placed during my Mastectomy, and once I healed from the surgery I started to go into the office and he injects the expander with saline. It is relatively painless, but I am sometimes a little sore afterwards. Right now my new breast is very slightly larger than the other one, but I can still pass. I have no idea how it is going to look in the end...right now my new breast is a LOT higher than my old one, and I have more cleavage than I have had since highschool(albiet on one side only). I will have to have another surgery to place my permanent implant, and I will have an augmentation and lift of my existing breast at the same time. Sounds like a lot of surgery...and I guess it is, but as I said, my options were limited, and I was not interested in spending the rest of my life with a prosthetic.

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2007 09:45AM Rebecca wrote: I also think that the term survivor comes out of the age when BC really was a life threatening condition, rather than a chronic one, as it is considered today. Nevertheless, it is still a battle, and a trying experience. It may be an outdated label, but it does denote membership in a group of women that is so large that it is both distressing (that it is so common) and inspiring (that it does not claim lives as it used to)

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2007 04:13AM Rebecca wrote: Hang in there...do not fret the hair. For me it is more the reminder that this is REAL that the bald head represents. There is no denying that you have cancer when your hair is coming out in your hands, and you have bald spots creeping up the back of your neck. In contrast to your experience, I find that I need to look at it so that I can remind myself of my fight and keep my focus. I view it as a sacrifice so that I can enjoy the years ahead with my wonderful husband and children (I have three...4,7, and 9). I gave up my breast, I gave up my hair. I can not look back because I will cry...but I can always look forward with hope. Be well, my sister...this will pass.

Posts.Title: my test results are back... newgirl77 althea

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2008 08:21AM Rebecca wrote: That is very good advice.  Honesty is always the best policy, particularly with children.  I do have a few bits of advice from my own experience that I am happy to share with you: When I told my daughters about it, my husband and I sat them down and explained (in essence) what cancer was without using the word until the very end because the word "cancer" has such scary connotations. be careful about the books that have been written for children because many of them are old and out of date, and will not accurately represent what  will be happening to YOU.  I would stick to your own words. my older daughter developed a conceptualization of chemo and what it does to you that helped her a lot:  She said that the chemo was like a superhero...it went into my body and beat up the bad guys (cancer cells), but like a real superhero battle, there was a lot of damage to the city (my body) as a result of the fight. This damage was worth it because the bad guys were vanquished, and the city will repair the damage. I think it is important to express to the children that your "sick" appearance is not because you are sick with cancer, but a result of the treatment.   Also, you should be aware that the chemo does not make your hair fall out immediately....it takes about 14 days for that to happen. My last comment is that you might wish to send a letter home to the parents BEFORE you speak to the children.  This way you do not step on toes, and you allow the parents to be prepared in case the children are upset.  You can do it!  stay in touch here.  There is a January chemo group here...join it!  I had my chemo last january, and i still talk to my chemo sisters who were and are an enormous blessing in my life. keep your head high and smile.   be well and good luck
Posts.Title: telling my class Angie WendyK

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2008 08:21AM Rebecca wrote: OMG Iodine...you are so right about that! When I was going through chemo I had my two daughters in public school (germ-hole #1) and my son was in preschool which is even WORSE if that is possible.  I was so terrified that I would get sick and have to delay treatment!  What I wound up doing was sending hand sanitizer in to the school and instructing the teachers to make sure that my kids cleaned their hands frequently so that THEY would not get sick, and hence not bring anything home to me.  we had the healthiest winter on record LOL! For you, Angie, since you are the teacher I think it is a bit more complicated.  I would suggest that you keep some hand sanitizer on your desk and clean  your hands after touching your children.  You might also advise the parents that you will be immune compromised and that they should therefore be very cautious in sending a sick child to school.  I am also a teacher (albiet for college kids) and I told MY students that if they were sick that they were forbidden to come near me. That said, the Neulasta that is often given does a pretty good job of keeping your immune system kicking. post back and let us know how it goes!
Posts.Title: telling my class Angie WendyK

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2008 08:56AM Rebecca wrote: Please do not give up hope!  Even if your node is positive, it is not a death sentance by any means.  When I had my mastectomy, they did a sentinal node biopsy, and found a single node with a metastasis inside it...but all of my other nodes were clear.  One of the things that my Dr told me was that the purpose of the lymph nodes is to filter out the bad stuff...and the fact that the first node in line was positive and the rest were clear could be interpreted as my nodes doing their job.  This is not to minimize your fear...I well remember the terror I felt about my  nodes. In fact, the first thing out of my mouth when I awoke in recovery was a question about my node status.  On the other hand, I am now over a year out and going strong.  I do not have any additional signs of disease and I feel great. Keep your head high, Goldie...you CAN do this, and all of your BC sisters are here to help you, guide you, and hold your hand.   (((HUGS)))

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2007 06:47AM Rebecca wrote: It is perfectly normal to be scared by an experience like yours.  That said, you and your doctors did everything that you can, and should do in this situation.  If the ultrasound was clear, and your FNA did not show any abnormal cells, the overwhelming likelihood is that it is a cyst, and nothing to worry about.  It is standard procedure to call you back in to re-evaluate in a few months, just to make sure that nothing has changed.  The fact that you need to go back in Feb does NOT mean that there is anything wrong, it is just your medical team being thorough. Best of luck to you and be well

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2008 05:57AM Rebecca wrote: I did not have a vacuum assist biopsy, although I have had two breast MRIs.  The breast MRI was not that big of a deal...mostly boring.  As far as the comments of the radiologist...I think it is extremely unprofessional to say the least.  It is difficult to tell if a lump is maligninant from US/Mammo alone...the only way to get a definitive diagnosis is to take a sample and look at it under a microscope.  I am sorry you have to go through this...and I am sure the conduct of this radiologist is not helping your frame of mind!  Hang in there, and keep us posted.  This community is a wonderful source of support and information.
